description: From Latin zephyrus (“west wind”), from Ancient Greek Ζέφυρος (Zéphuros).

entries.meaning: A light wind from the west.
Any light refreshing wind; a gentle breeze.
Anything of fine, soft, or light quality, especially fabric.

verbs.description: zephyr (third-person singular simple present zephyrs, present participle zephyring, simple past and past participle zephyred)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, poetic) To blow or move like a zephyr, or light breeze.
examples: When the soft zephyring spring came joyfully,
Like a young bride, with bloom upon her cheek—

entries.meaning: (transitive, poetic) To blow or blow on gently like a zephyr; to cool or refresh with a gentle breeze.
examples: He was a fragrant poison, a zephyred pestilence spread through all the city.
